13634 : Considering your current level and the knowledge you have, you shouldn't confine yourself to the immediate vicinity of the city. You're more than capable of besting monsters in [La Theine Plateau/the Konschtat Highlands/Tahrongi Canyon] at this point.
13635 : I knew you wouldn't disappoint me. So how's it feel? You're moving on up in the world. Time to put some money in those pockets. A #-gil reward, just for you. Don't spend it all in one place.
13636 : By now you should be relatively familiar with the basics of battle. Am I right or am I right?
13637 : But don't go getting too cocky! This world is chock-full of monsters just waiting for the opportune moment to pounce and knock you out cold!
13638 : Depending on the type of monster, there are several factors that could cause them to attack you without provocation. I'll enumerate some of the more common types of this blatantly aggressive behavior for you.
13639 : For starters, and most obviously, there are monsters which detect by sight. They will attack you whenever you enter their field of vision. This is the most prevalent type. They simply cannot stand the sight of adventurers.
13640 : Next, there are those monsters which detect by sound. They can be a bit more dangerous than visually-dependent monsters, in that they will attack the source of any sound within a certain prescribed radius. You may not think it, but there are a great many monsters whose aural senses are far more developed than their sense of sight.
13641 : There are also monsters which detect their enemies' spellcasting. Much like the sound-detecting types, these monsters will attack the source of any magic casting within a certain radius of their being. Not surprisingly, many monsters in the arcana family rely heavily on this method of detection, which covers a comparatively larger range than the aforementioned sense of hearing.
13642 : And finally, there are opportunistic monsters which prey upon the weak and near-dead, pinpointing their prey by detecting low hit points. The family of undead creatures abound in monsters of this type. Even more distressing, the fewer the hit points you have, the farther the distance from which you can be detected.
13643 : Your next assignment will attempt to familiarize you with these detection methods, and train you to become adept at avoiding them.
13644 : I want you to travel once again to [La Theine Plateau/the Konschtat Highlands/Tahrongi Canyon], and retrieve an item known as a Gate Crystal.
13645 : Near the center of [La Theine Plateau/the Konschtat Highlands/Tahrongi Canyon], you will find a large, white, almost otherworldly structure. On the area map, it is labeled as the [Crag of Holla/Crag of Dem/Crag of Mea].
13646 : There you will find one of an enormous series of crystals known as Telepoints. Simply examine the telepoint you find there, and bring back your findings.
13647 : Only when you present your % to me shall your assignment be complete.
13648 : Exercise the utmost caution. There are many extremely dangerous monsters in the area you will be visiting. And take extra care not to draw the attention of any beastmen.
13649 : This shall be your final assignment. Go now, and may the Goddess watch over you.
13650 : Ahhh, the %, just as I requested. Excellent work, %.
13651 : And now for some information regarding this little beauty. As long as you have this %, you will be able to be transported by the appropriate spell of teleportation directly to the telepoint from which you retrieved it.
13652 : I doubt that you will have many opportunities to use it for the time being, but you would do well to remember what I have said.
13653 : Several such telepoints exist, scattered throughout Vana'diel. Each has its own specific gate crystal, which you will receive the first time that you examine any of them.
13654 : Let me take this time to offer you a most heartfelt congratulations, %! You have successfully completed all of the assignments I have laid before you.
13655 : And here I have a most fitting reward for you. A gift of # experience points, and # %.
13656 : I fear that I have nothing more to teach you. From now on, your lessons will best be learned by giving a mindful ear to others and being ever observant on your travels.
13657 : Do remember, though, that the paths open before you will multiply greatly should you cooperate with other adventurers.
13658 : Leveling, for example, is an endeavor made immeasurably more efficient and enjoyable in the company of others. It helps to not only guarantee you some modicum of safety in numbers, but also rewards you with considerably more experience points than adventuring alone.
13659 : I suppose it does require a good deal of courage to approach an adventurer you do not know, but I strongly encourage you to do so. It may prove to be the beginning of an extremely rewarding and long-lasting friendship.
13660 : There may still be some small facets of adventuring that I can continue to offer you advice on. Should you ever have any questions or anxieties, please do not hesitate to come and see me again. I will do my best to be of service and set your heart at ease.

13662 : Good day to you! Guardian of the Kingdom, Alaune, at your most humble service. Is there something in particular I can help you with this day?
13663 : Good day to you! Defender of the Republic, Gulldago, at your most humble service. Is there something in particular I can help you with this day?
13664 : Good day to you! Protector of the Federation, Selele, at your most humble service.. Is there something in particular I can help you with this day?
13665 : What will you ask about? Nothing just now. Search comments. Skillchains. Magic bursts. Skillchains and elements.
13666 : Just as their name implies, search comments are original messages composed by adventurers which are readily visible to others when using the search function.
13667 : There are several different categories of search comments. These include, but are not limited to, EXP Party, Items, and Missions and Quests.
13668 : Opening the Search function from the Main Menu and then selecting the Comment option will allow you to conduct a player search by comment type.
13669 : For example, if you would like to search for other players to form a leveling party, you need only select EXP Party from the list displayed.
13670 : Conversely, if you would like to advertise yourself as interested in being on the receiving end of an experience party invite, you can choose the Edit Comment command from the Search menu.
13671 : Of course, search comment composition differs from person to person. You might want to conduct a search first to see what type of search comments are considered the norm before writing your own.
13672 : Skillchains are devastating elemental phenomena which manifest themselves when weapon skills are carried out in a precise and well-timed order.
13673 : The very natures of the skillchains themselves differ widely, being dependent upon the weapon skills used and the order of their execution.
13674 : To take a simple and timeless example, using the weapon skill Red Lotus Blade immediately after Fast Blade will yield a type of skillchain known as Liquefaction.
13675 : Furthermore, adding a Combo after the liquefaction effect will produce a more advanced Fusion skillchain.
13676 : In the taxonomy of skillchains, each type is related to one or more specific elements. Liquefaction is bound to the element of fire, for example, and fusion to both fire and light.
13677 : Another crucial point, which I simply cannot emphasize enough, is the importance of timing in the execution of skillchains.
13678 : One must not be too overzealous, but too much patience can also be damning. It is most ideal to time the latter weapon skill to begin just a second or two after the preceding one is complete.
13679 : The possible weapon skill sequences and the different skillchains they yield are highly variegated. It is said of this time-tested battle art that it takes a moment to learn, and a lifetime to master.
13680 : Magic bursts are another type of supernatural phenomena which occur after carefully selected and impeccably timed spells are cast following a skillchain. Such spells exceed their typical counterparts in that they are enhanced in both power and accuracy. You will commonly see magic bursts abbreviated as MB.
13681 : Magic bursts will not take place if the element of the spell being cast does not match the element of the skillchain preceding it.
13682 : To take an example, a detonation skillchain, which has wind as its element, followed by an aero or other like spell, will generate a magic burst.
13683 : In the same vein, thunder, or any cognate spell, would result in a magic burst should it follow an impaction skillchain, itself deriving power from that very element.
13684 : As I said previously, some skillchains are associated with more than one element. Take fragmentation, for example. It is composed of equal parts wind and thunder. So chasing a fragmentation skillchain with any type of aero or thunder spell would create a magic burst.
13685 : The key to mastering magic bursts lies in learning the elemental attributes of both the skillchains you create as well as the magic you wield. The rest is simply a matter of timing.
13686 : For your convenience, I will go over the elemental attributes of all skillchain types. Pay close attention.
13687 : Level 1 Skillchain (Associated element): Transfixion (Light), Liquefaction (Fire), Detonation (Wind), Impaction (Thunder), Induration (Ice), Reverberation (Water), Scission (Earth), Compression (Darkness).
13688 : Level 2 Skillchain (Associated elements): Fusion (Light/Fire), Fragmentation (Wind/Thunder), Distortion (Ice/Water), Gravitation (Earth/Darkness).
13689 : Level 3 Skillchain (Associated elements): Light (Light/Fire/Wind/Thunder), Darkness (Ice/Water/Earth/Darkness).

13867 : Ask about what? Nothing. Synergy furnaces. Synergy overview. Synergy procedure. Synergy recipes. Fewell replenishment. Materials for sale. Synergy techniques. Trading cinder.
13868 : The synergy furnaces you see around town are provided as a public service by the Bastokan Institute of Synergy Research, to ensure that no synergist is ever far away from the tools of their trade.
13869 : The synergist must provide his or her own %, as well as any materials to be used in the synergy process. Provided those conditions are met, synergy furnaces may be used free of charge.
13870 : Needless to say, only one party may operate any given furnace at once.
13871 : Fortunately, there are multiple furnaces installed throughout town. If the furnace before you is already in use, please seek out an unused one elsewhere, or wait patiently for your turn.
13872 : You may think of synergy as an evolved form of synthesis. It is a discipline full of heretofore unimagined possibilities, but one which demands consummate skill from its practitioners.
13873 : Like synthesis, synergy involves combining materials according to a prescribed recipe to yield oft-spectacular results. The rub is that each synergy recipe also dictates a certain elemental balance that must be achieved for the procedure to be successful.
13874 : This balance is achieved through skillful infusion of combustible elemental crystals that we synergists call fewell. To begin the synergy process, you'll have to feed the furnace with fewell and get those flames burning!
13875 : As a general rule, the more complex the recipe, the more fewell it will require. Take care to check your stock before you fire up the furnace, lest you find its flames guttering out at a crucial moment.
13876 : With the belly of the furnace roaring up a storm, it's time to toss in your materials and start synergizing! Keep a close eye on the balance of elements and deploy fewell as necessary. Approach the prescribed elemental balance, and your item will take form, allowing you to remove it from the furnace.
13877 : The closer you are to the ideal elemental balance, the higher the quality of your finished product will be. In synergy, it pays to be a perfectionist!
13878 : But be forewarned: these furnaces can only sustain the elemental maelstrom swirling and storming inside them for so long.
13879 : If the furnace's durability should fail, the synergy process will be interrupted, and you will be forced to start anew.
13880 : Take heart, though, as any materials inside your % will remain intact. You may retrieve them or attempt the synergy process again as you see fit.
13881 : Any fewell consumed in the failed synergy attempt, on the other hand, will be permanently lost.
13882 : Synergists must also be wary of debris buildup, an unavoidable side effect of the volatile elemental reactions that take place within the synergy furnace.
13883 : Should too much debris be allowed to accumulate, the contents of the furnace will become unstable, potentially leading to unpleasant explosions and eruptions. Such accidents pose considerable risk to the synergy attempt in progress, as well as the physical well-being of the synergist, so be sure to exercise due caution!
13884 : You may be asking yourself, Why, how in the name of Hildolf am I going to oversee all of these complicated procedures and variables by myself?
13885 : Here's the good news: you don't have to! For you see, synergy furnaces are designed for use by multiple operators.
13886 : The more complex the recipe, the greater level of skill and hands-on manipulation it will demand. At such times, it would be in your best interest to seek out like-minded synergists and take on the challenge together.
13887 : Finally, it would be remiss of me not to make mention of %, the curious substance whose properties are only now--with the emergence of synergy--becoming known to us.
13888 : Though there is much yet to be learned, our research has revealed that % may be used to bolster your equipment, if attached in a proper manner.
13889 : Mind you, % is not easy to come by, and I can offer no clues as to where or how to obtain it. Should you be fortunate enough to come across some in your travels, however, I encourage you to explore its potential.
13890 : Synergy is not a discipline for the faint of heart or mind, but with dedication and cooperation, there are great rewards to be reaped. May your career as a synergist prove fruitful!
13891 : First, you'll be wanting to check your fewell supply. You may do so by speaking with a synergy engineer such as myself, or by examining a synergy furnace.
13892 : You'll be needing at least one unit of fewell for each element dictated by your recipe. Without this, even the most skilled synergist cannot hope to succeed.
13893 : Should your fewell supply be in order, it's time to proceed with the synergy. If you are using one of these public synergy furnaces here, you'll need to examine it and lay claim to its use.
13894 : You may then deposit your ingredients. Should they correspond to a proper recipe, the synergy furnace will fire up automatically. Note that as a safety precaution, the furnace will not activate if the recipe is beyond your level of synergy skill.
13895 : From here, it becomes a race against the clock! Through skilled operation of the synergy furnace, you must achieve the elemental balance prescribed by the recipe before the furnace's durability fails.
13896 : Fortunately, synergy furnaces are outfitted with a wide array of features designed to aid the synergist in this demanding task. First, you'll want to confirm the current balance of elements within the furnace and compare it to your desired result.
13897 : Next, you can begin to feed fewell into the furnace to gradually raise the level of elemental concentration. Feeding fewell into the furnace until the required elemental balance is achieved is the most fundamental operation of synergy.
13898 : However, high concentrations of elemental power can lead to volatile and unpredictable reactions. Simply adding fewell haphazardly without making the necessary adjustments is a recipe for only one thing, and that's disaster.
13899 : If you sense that the furnace is on the verge of elemental overload, you'll want to employ the safety lever and pressure handle to prevent an unfortunate accident from occurring.
13900 : You'll also want to mind the laws of elemental ascendancy and opposition. Increasing the concentration of a particular element will cause its counterpart to decrease.
13901 : The furnace cannot sustain its power indefinitely, and will gradually lose durability as the synergy process continues. You'll need to perform periodic furnace repair should the furnace near its breaking point.
13902 : It is also possible to recycle strewn fewell during synergy. While this will not impact the success or failure of the process itself, it will result in a greater amount of salvageable cinder produced as a by-product.
13903 : This cinder is of great interest to our researchers back at the institute. As such, we have introduced a reward system through which quality samples can be traded in for an assortment of synergy-related wares.
13904 : As marvelous an apparatus as the synergy furnace may be, keep in mind that the technology is still in its infancy, and highly unstable. There may be times when accidents occur despite the best efforts of the synergist.
13905 : For your safety, we recommend stepping as far away from the furnace as possible at the first sign of danger. Some synergists claim that giving the furnace a good thwack is also effective in preventing such accidents, but this is pure madness, if you ask me!
13906 : You will also find that there are numerous techniques that can be applied to make the synergy procedure go even more smoothly.
13907 : In many cases, expertise and knowledge acquired through crafting will serve you in synergy as well. To truly master synergy, one must master crafting as well.
13908 : Now let us return to the synergy process itself. As your elemental balance approaches that prescribed by the recipe, the furnace will signal you, and you may retrieve your finished product.
13909 : If the furnace is still holding strong at this time, you may choose to keep working to achieve an even closer balance. The closer you come to the ideal balance, the higher the quality of your finished product will be.
13910 : Indeed, many synergy masters consider these waning moments after the signal to be the time to really show off their skills! Why, if they manage to achieve an elemental surge...
13911 : What's an elemental surge, you ask? Why, it's a miraculous phenomenon that occurs rarely--ever so rarely--upon feeding the furnace fewell.
13912 : The elements react just in the right way, creating a miraculous reaction that brings the level of elemental concentration to exactly the desired level. Truly a boon from the Goddess for any synergist, no?
13913 : ...And that is the synergy process in a nutshell. There's quite a bit of information to take in, so don't hesitate to return any time for a refresher course.
13914 : Much like synthesis, to fashion items through synergy, you will need to follow a recipe. We synergy engineers are always unearthing new recipes, and are happy to share with you those suitable for your level of skill.
13915 : Unlike synthesis, however, a synergy recipe is more than just a list of ingredients. There is also a required elemental balance that must be attained to achieve your desired result.
13916 : Simple recipes involve only small doses of a limited number of elements, but more complex ones require the synergist to skillfully juggle wide ranges of elements in extremely high concentrations.
13917 : The ingredients, you will have to remember on your own. The required elemental balance, however, may be reviewed at any time during the synergy process by observing the readings on the synergy furnace.
13918 : In particular, recipes through which the curious substance known as % can be attached to equipment are creating quite a buzz among synergistically inclined adventurers these days.
13919 : % cannot be attached directly. First, equipment must be prepared by etching an aperture into which an elementally compatible piece of % can then be embedded.
13920 : The type of aperture that may be etched will depend on the piece of equipment. There are also pieces of equipment that, alas, may not be modified at all.
13921 : If you are curious what manner of aperture may be etched into a particular piece of equipment, you need only trade it to me or one of my colleagues.
13922 : As a general rule, the higher the level of the item in question, the more difficult the synergy process for creating an aperture will be.
13923 : You will find that certain pieces of equipment may be etched with multiple apertures. It is, however, only possible to create one aperture at a time.
13924 : Etching requires the use of a corrosive substance we call mordant. Deposit mordant into a synergy furnace along with your equipment, and the process will begin.
13925 : My colleagues and I have a stock of mordant available for sale. The best way to learn is to practice, so if you're curious, we encourage you to purchase some and begin experimenting!
13926 : The difficulty of the synergy process when embedding evolith is decided by a number of factors.
13927 : Such factors include the variety of aperture and evolith, as well as the quantity of evolith you seek to attach. Embedding the first piece is not too difficult a task, but the second and third pieces will not go in so easily.
13928 : To begin the embedding process, deposit your evolith into the synergy furnace along with a piece of equipment with a compatible aperture.
13929 : When etching or embedding, the required elemental balance may be confirmed at any time during the synergy process, so let this be your guide.
13930 : Should you ever wish to remove any apertures and embedded evolith from a piece of equipment entirely, you may do so with an ingredient we call revertant.
13931 : Toss the revertant in a synergy furnace along with your equipment, and its potent powers will restore your item to a pure and pristine state! Be warned, however, that embedded evolith will be lost forever in the process.
13932 : As you are no doubt already aware, synergy makes use of a highly combustible form of elemental crystals that we call fewell. The more complex the recipe, the greater the quantity of fewell required.
13933 : Veteran synergists know well the hassle of having to constantly monitor their fewell supply and procure crystals to replenish depleted stock.
13934 : To free you of such trifling burdens and allow you to focus your mind entirely on your art, we synergy engineers are offering a convenient fewell replenishment service!
13935 : For a nominal fee calculated based upon the current state of your fewell reserves, we will instantly refill you to full capacity.
13936 : That's right--all elements in one simple transaction, directly to your %! What could be easier?
13937 : Looking to fire up your furnace and enter the world of %? If so, you've come to the right place!
13938 : We're proud to offer a supply of the corrosive agent known as mordant for sale. With this, synergy newcomers can hone their skills and outfit their equipment with evolith-capable apertures in the process.
13939 : Mind you, our stock is limited to only the most diluted, readily produced form of the stuff. You'll find that it only has the strength to etch items of relatively low level.
13940 : Etching high-powered equipment requires the use of more concentrated and potent forms of mordant. As quantities are limited, we can offer these only in exchange for cinder.
13941 : Ah, synergy techniques! Those handy tricks of the trade that can mean the difference between a shiny new item and a major furnace meltdown.
13942 : My colleagues and I are always eager to train fellow synergists in a wide range of techniques. We can't do it all, though--you'll need to hone your synergy skill in order to benefit from our instruction.
13943 : Bear in mind that certain techniques can only be imparted to students possessing specialized crafting knowledge. For example, only skilled smiths will be able to comprehend the method for more efficient fewell feeding.
13944 : Accomplished goldsmiths will be able to observe the inner workings of the furnace and stave off potential accidents. You will find that all crafting skills--even those you may not expect--may be applied in some way to support the synergy process.
13945 : Word has it that there are also pieces of equipment that can impart hidden synergy techniques to the wearer. These, too, are said to be only accessible to skilled crafters.
13946 : The moral of the story is this: while synergy skill is important, neglect not your other crafting skills. To become a true synergy master, finding the proper balance is key.
13947 : Synergy remains a young discipline, and researchers back at the institute are burning the midnight fewell in the hopes of uncovering the next breakthrough in our field.
13948 : Research of late is centered around the cinder that is left behind as a by-product of each synergy operation. Their composition, it would seem, has much to teach us of the true nature of the complex elemental reactions that go on within the bellies of these furnaces.
13949 : We've even instituted a reward program for adventurers willing to contribute prime samples in the name of science.
13950 : It would be no exaggeration to say that, to us, cinder is worth more than its weight in gold! Bring it to me or my colleagues--preferably in large quantities--and you're sure to be pleased at what we can offer you in return.
13951 : Wondering if your % can be outfitted with evolith, are you? Well, you've come to the right place!
13952 : A quick look at its composition should tell us all we need to know. Let's see here...
13953 : Congratulations! Your % can indeed hold [an/another] evolith aperture. A %-shaped aperture, to be exact...

13972 : Using % in conjunction with a synergy furnace--the apparatus you see beside me--the synergist wields the power of myriad elements to fabricate a veritable host of potent items.
13973 : What we call % serves to dispense fewell crystals--the lifeblood of the synergy process--whilst also protecting its contents from the volatile reactions that occur within the bowels of the furnace.
13974 : Synergy furnaces have been installed throughout the city for the use of all synergists. The crucible is sufficiently compact and lightweight that you can carry it with you.
13975 : Initiating the synergy process is as simple as inserting your % into a furnace and commencing the infusion of elemental fewell.
13976 : Needless to say, what will happen from there is not quite so simple.
13977 : Successful synergy is contingent upon maintaining elemental equilibrium. The prescribed ratio, of course, will vary depending on the artifact you are attempting to create.
13978 : You can increase the ratio of a particular element by burning the corresponding variety of fewell.
13979 : But herein lies the rub: synergy is a still young science, and the technology we employ remains, shall we say...unstable.
13980 : A bit too much fewell here, a wrong lever pulled there, and the percolating pot will explode, spitting scalding elemental guck every which way to Firesday.
13981 : That's why smart synergists synergize in numbers. Too many culinarians might spoil the broth, but when it comes to synergy, it's the more the merrier!
13982 : An aspiring synergist, I see! If you're looking for %, you've certainly come to the right place.

13984 : # gil, paid in full!

13995 : What's that? You wish to hear of my father? Forgive me, but I'm far too busy to indulge in idle reminiscing.
13996 : Perhaps you can seek out my son Ailbeche. The boy was quite close to his grandfather.
13997 : Why, those %...!
13998 : They bear a remarkable resemblance to a prized possession of my dear departed father's. Oh, the memories this brings back!
13999 : Father was quite the ardent angler, you see. In fact, I cannot recall a single day that he did not make the trip to Lake Mechieume.
14000 : Oh, of course he'd spare an hour here or there to instruct me in swordplay. A gesture for which I was most thankful, to be sure.
14001 : But this was but a diversion for him. That angling was his true passion was clear for all to see.
14002 : So all-consuming was his obsession that I grew to resent him. What kind of father could harbor a greater love for fishing than for his own family?
14003 : As it turns out, I had misjudged the man.
14004 : I heard the truth from my mother one day. Fishing as a craft was of little interest to him, she said.
14005 : And yet, it was an age of war, with foodstuffs few and far between.
14006 : This is what drove my father to make the perilous journey through Jugner Forest each and every dawn. A desire to provide sustenance, not just to his own beloved family, but to his suffering countrymen as well.
14007 : The father I had seen as little but a cruel taskmaster was, in fact, a deeply honorable, self-sacrificing soul.
14008 : I was instilled with a newfound pride, and swore that one day I would instill my son with the same values that my father had stood for.
14009 : 'Tis a comical twist of fate, is it not? In the end, all that he inherited from his grandfather was his skill with the rod and lure.
14010 : My apologies. Whatever has gotten into me, to get so caught up in trivial nostalgia?

14039 : Atmacite is best described as the crystalline agglomeration of a creature's soul. Our scientists have succeeded in discovering a way to tap its power to serve the efforts of the Voidwatch.
14040 : By infusing one's body with atmacite, it is possible to obtain powers akin to those once possessed by the creature whence it came, rather like turning a beast's fangs upon its own kind.
14041 : At first glance, atmacite appears to be the perfect artificial enhancement. However, it does suffer from a single limitation: its power is unleashed only when engaged in a Voidwatch operation.
14042 : Research to identify the exact reason for this continues, but most scientists find the spectral alignment theory compelling.
14043 : That is, being formed of Voidwalker souls, atmacite will surge to life only when its bearer is existentially aligned to its dimension of origin.
14044 : From this it can be inferred that Voidwalkers are stripped of considerable strength when they cross over into Vana'diel.
14045 : But I suspect this is of little interest to a layman like you. Allow me to return to the subject at hand.
14046 : The infusion of atmacite requires cruor, a potent energy source that takes the form of shiny red granules.
14047 : Cruor is obtainable by various means, felling a Voidwalker being the most common of all. As you can never have too much cruor, I urge you to be diligent in its procurement.
14048 : We've recently perfected a method for improving atmacite potency. The process is called enrichment, and involves fusing cruor on to atmacite to amplify its power.
14049 : Atmacite can be enriched in stages up to a maximum of level #. The quantity of cruor required varies with the variety of atmacite as well as its current enrichment level.
14050 : Under normal conditions, atmacite enrichment is an intensive process that demands trained hands. For reasons yet to be determined, however, both infusion and enrichment can be safely performed by laymen, provided they're at a planar rift.
14051 : Keep this in mind should the need arise to reconfigure your atmacite with haste.

14853 : What will you ask about? Nothing. The Voidwalker threat. How I can do my part. The Voidwatch. Voidwatchers. Ascent items. Riftworn pyxides. %. Stratum abyssite. Planar rifts. Cruor. Abyssite. Voidstone consumption.
14854 : Voidwalker is the name given to creatures that roam the realm between worlds.
14855 : Little is known about them at this time, except that they're driven by an insatiable lust for destruction.
14856 : While reports of Voidwalker encounters vary greatly in content, one thing is certain: the creatures are gaining in strength, a mounting threat that cannot be left unchecked.
14857 : In our effort to neutralize the Voidwalker menace, the Voidwatch is petitioning adventurers to lend their aid.
14858 : As the nature of Voidwalker battles renders full-scale military operations unfeasible, we have chosen to stake our success on the mobility and versatility of adventurers.
14859 : In our effort to neutralize the Voidwalker menace, the Voidwatch is petitioning soldiers of the Allied Forces to lend their aid.
14860 : To be sure, there're those who question the wisdom of thinning our ranks in the face of the Shadow Lord's armies. But I assure you, friend, the Voidwalker threat is no less real.
14861 : Our scouts regularly bring back intel on locations of suspected Voidwalker presence.
14862 : Armed with this information, we dispatch strike teams to preemptively neutralize the threat.
14863 : Ordinarily, Voidwalkers cannot be seen, let alone fought. Only by using the voidstone's power can we force them to feel the sting of our steel.
14864 : These magicked stones are distributed in regular shipments from our Jeuno-based research team. They're the bare minimum we need to have a fighting chance against the enemy.
14865 : Voidstones work by realigning your existential spectrum to match that of Voidwalkers, thus rendering the creatures visible to you.
14866 : The stones are highly prized, such is the difficulty of their creation. As such, supplies are limited to # stones per person at any given time.
14867 : That's provided we have any in stock at all. Much time is required in imbuing them with requisite powers.
14868 : The Voidwatch is an organization that exists for the sole purpose of protecting the world from extradimensional invaders we call Voidwalkers.
14869 : Recognizing the graveness of this threat, the nations of the Middle Lands joined together in common cause and formed the Voidwatch.
14870 : Helming the organization is the Grand Duchy of Jeuno, with the remaining three nations contributing resources for its operation.
14871 : Possession of % is a requirement for participating in Voidwatch Ops.
14872 : It can be earned only through loyal service to your nation, and thus serves as a testimonial for your prowess.
14873 : You would do well to obtain one if you haven't already done so.
14874 : Affiliation with the Allied Forces of Altana is a requirement for participating in Voidwatch Ops.
14875 : In other words, you must belong to the armed forces of one of the three nations.
14876 : The enlistment procedure varies depending on nation. Those wishing to obtain a recommendation letter should pay visit to one of the military encampments surrounding Jeuno.
14877 : When you battle a Voidwalker, you must do so as a Voidwatcher--a defender of the dimension who has harnessed the powers of the voidstone and stratum abyssite.
14878 : Bereft of these two objects, Voidwalkers cannot be seen, let alone fought.
14879 : However, there are a few points all budding Voidwatchers should bear in mind.
14880 : Most crucial of all, the extradimensional nature of being a Voidwatcher renders you isolated and unable to receive help from the outside world.
14881 : Scientists attribute this to the dimensional misalignment that occurs. As people are ordinarily unable to see Voidwalkers, so too are they unable to see you.
14882 : But you needn't concern yourself with the hows and whys of such matters. It would behoove you far more to become familiar with the workings of the existential spectrum.
14883 : You see, each dimension is composed of an existential spectrum to which all things within are aligned. In turn, the spectrum is formed of five lights: blue, red, yellow, green, and white.
14884 : The alignment of these lights between Voidwalker and Voidwatcher plays an important role in our efforts.
14885 : To elaborate, the act of rendering a Voidwalker visible is essentially an act of aligning ourselves to its existential spectrum.
14886 : Now, while Voidwatchers are able to, for all practical purposes, interact with these creatures, they in fact fall short of full alignment. Symptoms of this imperfect state can be observed in the limited quantity and quality of spoils normally yielded by Voidwalkers.
14887 : Compensating measures, however, have been developed to allow combatants to more closely attune themselves with their extradimensional foe.
14888 : One such method involves the use of alignment-enhancing artifacts known as ascent items, while another entails performing certain actions against the enemy.
14889 : Both methods aim to manipulate the alignment value of individual lights to various ends.
14890 : All five lights influence the contents of the treasure chest which appears at the successful end of battle.
14891 : Our researchers have succeeded in determining what manner of benefits are associated with each light.
14892 : For instance, improving blue spectral alignment is known to produce greater quantities of spoils.
14893 : In contrast, manipulating red spectral alignment reportedly enhances the quality of individual items--potions becoming hi-potions, and so forth.
14894 : Yellow and green, on the other hand, influence experience gain and cruor yield respectively.
14895 : If you wish to know more about the curious red substance we call cruor, you need but ask.
14896 : Lastly, we have white spectral alignment, which is unique even in this company. It has been determined to affect the appearance of transdimensional objects such as atmacite and periapt.
14897 : Research regarding these artifacts is still ongoing.
14898 : Lastly, be reassured that there're no known negative effects of manipulating spectral alignment. We unreservedly encourage all Voidwatch operatives to endeavor towards maximum alignment.
14899 : Ascent items are unique objects that can be used to manipulate the spectral alignment of corresponding lights in the existential spectrum.
14900 : % and % are representative of such items. They're the pride and joy of our Jeuno-based research team, who'd have folk believe they're the greatest inventions since airships.
14901 : (Just between you and me, though, it is Far Eastern scientists that pioneered the technology they're based upon.)
14902 : They're not the only means by which we manipulate spectral alignment, mind you. Similar results can be achieved by performing specific actions against the enemy.
14903 : Truth be told, much is still shrouded in mystery. What actions will produce the desired effect is something you will have to discover for yourself through trial and error.
14904 : Defeating a Voidwalker will cause a mysterious pyxis to emerge at the selfsame planar rift whence the creature was felled.
14905 : Such riftworn pyxides exhibit a most peculiar characteristic: the content they bear reportedly changes depending on who glimpses within.
14906 : Our scientists conjecture that this is due to some trick of spectral alignment. As with numerous other mysteries surrounding Voidwalkers, however, I highly doubt they have even an inkling of understanding. But I digress...
14907 : Only one combatant need possess a voidstone for all party or alliance members to do battle with a Voidwalker. Of the other squad members only stratum abyssite is required.
14908 : As always seems to be the case, however, there is a catch. Pyxides have been observed to yield less spoils for combatants without a voidstone of their own.
14909 : It scarce needs be said, but it would be to your benefit to have both the aforementioned items readied before taking on a Voidwalker.
14910 : Lastly, a warning: pyxides will eventually vanish if left untouched overlong. Our scientists have put forth the theory of normalizing spatial dissonance, but you needn't concern yourself with their mumbo-jumbo.
14911 : Just see to it that your hard-earned spoils are claimed in good time, and things will be rosy for all involved.
14912 : The % is a magicked object produced by the Voidwatch's Jeuno-based research wing.
14913 : Its innocuous appearance belies the immense power it holds...the power to render Voidwalkers visible to its bearer.
14914 : The stone achieves this feat by realigning our existential spectrum to that of the creature.
14915 : I shall explain the process in layman's terms for your benefit. No need to thank me--I merely perform my duty.
14916 : I want you to visualize two canvases, each the same distance from the other. Yes, as two separate objects are normally wont to be.
14917 : Imagine you and I standing on one of the canvases--what else does one do with a canvas but stand on it, yes?
14918 : Now, imagine Voidwalkers standing on the other canvas, doing whatever it is Voidwalkers do. Destroying things and behaving with utter impropriety, no doubt.
14919 : Being on two different canvases, it follows that we cannot touch the Voidwalkers, let alone see them. Actually, that doesn't explain why we can't see the Voidwalkers...unless it's a magical canvas they're on that makes all things upon it invisible! Yes, that'll serve!
14920 : And this brings us full circle back to the voidstone. I want you to think of it as a magical paintbrush that we use to...grapple ourselves over to the Voidwalkers' canvas. Thence the fighting begins.
14921 : I trust you now have a rudimentary understanding of the process. That's all you need, really. Leave the fractal geometry to the fractal geometrists, I always say.
14922 : As long as you remember the canvas and the paintbrush--that's the voidstone--you cannot go astray. Now, to apprise you of more practical matters...
14923 : Twenty hours (Earth time) is required to produce a stone and imbue it with the necessary magicks, although word is that this may be shortened as research progresses.
14924 : Mind you, this isn't the only variety of stone you'll be needing. There exists another: stratum abyssite.
14925 : Whereas the voidstone serves as a power source, acting as a compass for channeling that power is stratum abyssite. Only by using the two in conjunction can we achieve our objectives.
14926 : Are you familiar with voiddust? Put simply, it is a granular substance from which voidstones may be fabricated.
14927 : As I explained, significant time is required to produce a voidstone from scratch. Provide me with voiddust, however, and I can fashion a stone for you in short order.
14928 : The same comrades of ours who stock ascent items may also furnish you with voiddust. Why do they not fabricate the stones themselves, or deliver the dust directly to me? Shush! The Voidwatch works in mysterious ways, and it would behoove you to inquire no further.
14929 : At any rate, should you manage to obtain any voiddust in your travels, you need only return here and trade it to me. Simple enough, wouldn't you say?
14930 : Furthermore, this particular variety of abyssite is known to absorb the energy released by felled Voidwalkers. Not any of the creatures, mind you, but only those drawn to planar rifts.
14931 : Based on the evolutionary state of your stratum abyssite, the Voidwatch will direct you to a suitable operation area.
14932 : If you wish to have your stone analyzed, simply present it to an atma refiner.
14933 : Planar rifts--weak points in the fabric of space--have manifested across the land. The Voidwalker hordes roam beyond, unchecked and ever seeking to enter and plunge Vana'diel into chaos.
14934 : By invoking the power of stratum abyssite, it is possible to battle the fell creatures as a Voidwatcher--a defender of our dimension.
14935 : Those also possessed of a voidstone will find their Voidwatcher experience greatly enhanced.
14936 : Alone, however, stratum abyssite serves no purpose; only when used in conjunction with a voidstone can its powers be unleashed.
14937 : Hence, at least one member of your squad--be it party or alliance--must possess a voidstone in order to arrange a confrontation with a Voidwalker.
14938 : Keep this fact in mind at all times.
14939 : It is not known when the planar rifts first manifested. Some say they've always been there, while others claim recent events have triggered their appearance.
14940 : If only we could return to the past, perhaps we could shed some light upon this mystery...
14941 : Obtainable by defeating Voidwalkers, cruor is an energy source that takes the form of shiny red granules.
14942 : While appearing to be some manner of mineral, detailed analysis has revealed that cruor is in fact organic.
14943 : As far as our researchers can tell, however, it's inanimate like most well-behaved plants. There's no fear of cruor suddenly springing to life in your palms.
14944 : Being supremely pleasing to the eyes, cruor might have adorned the display cases of many a jewelry shop during peacetime. Unfortunately, the age demands that its unique properties be put to more practical uses.
14945 : Namely, the infusion and enrichment of atmacite. If you wish to learn about these two processes, you need but ask an atmacite refiner, our experts on such matters.
14946 : As cruor is a vital aspect of our operations, the Voidwatch is always looking to procure more. Should you have any excess cruor, we would be glad to take it off your hands and offer you useful items in exchange.
14947 : Abyssite is the name given to a mysterious stone that assumes various forms and colors, the roles they serve likewise manifold in nature.
14948 : Of the copious varieties thus far discovered, there exist those called periapt--lucky charms that grant myriad beneficial effects ranging from improved vitality to general upturns in fortune.
14949 : Defeating a Voidwalker is known to yield periapt on very rare occasions. Serve the Voidwatch earnestly, however, and you will surely have one to call your own.

15508 : Hail, friend! No need to be so fleet of foot. Come, let me impart upon you a tantalizing morsel of information.
15509 : A [freshly hatched/well-traveled/high-class] adventurer such as yourself could surely appreciate the offer I am about to lay forth for your consideration.
15510 : I, Gondebaud, am an esteemed member of the storied Jeuno Institute of Magical Studies.
15511 : Mayhap I am repeating what you already know, but Jeuno is a grand city far to the southeast of here that connects the Quon and Mindartia continents.
15512 : The leading council has bid me come to this fair land of San d'Oria with a most sacred mission.
15513 : Several moons past, our famed institute held a lavish symposium at which we made privy to the public information about a new form of magic.
15514 : These new forms of incantations, which we call Trust, would prove a mighty boon to adventurers of your caliber.
15515 : A bevy of new experiences await should you choose to participate in this grand experiment. Will you embark on a journey to this fresh new world?
15516 : Participate in the experiment? I'd love to. I'm not sure it's for me.
15517 : You leave my jaw so agape that I fear my dentures are starting to slip!
15518 : How fortuitous! I swear by every gray hair on this head that you will not regret it! Your first task is to head to the city gates in Northern San d'Oria.
15519 : There you will find someone engaged in the running of Ballista, a type of mock skirmish. Some call him by the moniker of the grand hero of San d'Oria.
15520 : As you have already surmised, experimental magic may have unknown effects on the world, so he is very careful to ensure the safety of everyone involved.
15521 : In fact, he is so dedicated to this goal that he himself stepped up as the nation's first participant in the program.
15522 : The two other grand nations--Bastok and Windurst--have also seen others step up to try their hand at this wonderful manifestation of the arcane.
15523 : But we will leave those journeys for a later date. Your first step starts here, in San d'Oria, where you will garner the services of one of Vana'diel's most storied heroes.
15524 : Participate here in San d'Oria? Yes. No.
15525 : As I previously alluded to, there are more like me stationed in the other nations. They will guide you in much the same way, so please--lend an ear when you travel abroad.
15526 : Stupendous! Under my expert tutelage here in San d'Oria, you will surely grasp the basics of Trust in no time!
15527 : Take this letter of introduction with you and head to Ranperre Gate in Northern San d'Oria.
15528 : To get to Northern San d'Oria, you must first head west of here, then north toward Victory Square.
15529 : After reaching Northern San d'Oria, you are to make for Ranperre Gate. Once there, seek out Excenmille--and pray do not affront him in any fashion. The words of a hero such as he carry unmatched weight in this land.
15530 : Do you require an explanation as to what Trust is?
15531 : Inquire about what? What Trust is. What happens when one uses Trust. How to learn new Trust spells. Whereabouts of Trust participants. Nothing at the moment.
15532 : Trust is a new series of magical incantations woven into being by the Jeuno Institute of Magical Studies, announced at our recent symposium.
15533 : Mayhaps the term incantations is a trifle misleading. Rather than draw upon aetheric manipulation, Trust taps into the spiritual connection between those bound by [fraternal/sororal] love.
15534 : To lead you to my explanation's logical conclusion, I'll say this magic can be utilized regardless of its wielder's vocation. Both simple and profitable.
15535 : As the technique is reliant upon the connection between two souls, interference by a profusion of souls, such as in cities, renders the technique unusable.
15536 : Using Trust magic enables the caster to call forth alter egos of those with whom [he/she] has formed bonds of friendship and trust.
15537 : As this technique utilizes the resonance between two kindred spirits, the alter ego which manifests always matches the caster, be they weak or strong.
15538 : Journeys are much more satisfying when you have a companion, don't you think? The alter ego you summon will fight bravely by your side, but you will be unable to present them with detailed tactical orders.
15539 : If you wish to return the alter ego from whence it came, you only need speak to it and express your desire. A bittersweet moment, to be sure.
15540 : Alter egos suffer wounds just like you and I, and if one falls in battle, it will wink out of existence. To watch one so dear fade away...it brings a tear to your eye, does it not?
15541 : Yet fret not, my disciple! After just a short while you will be able to bring it back to the world once more. Your sadness will be but whispers on the wind.
15542 : Bringing forth an alter ego is not a simple process. You must first forge intangible bonds with those whose aid you wish to enlist.
15543 : Carefully cultivate trust and respect between yourself and a practitioner, as this technique cannot work unless the bonds between you be surer than steel.
15544 : Know you the adage opposites attract? Assuredly, such is not the case here. Storied personages have little time for those whose deeds are not sung as widely as their own.
15545 : But all I have just told you can be circumvented, as research into new methods of calling forth alter egos has been ongoing. It is possible to summon one without having so much as met the person.
15546 : As you can imagine, this requires a bit of tinkering with the aether, but it is indeed possible. All I require is the appropriate scroll.
15547 : Do you wish to drink from the font of knowledge?
15548 : [Excenmille/Naji/Kupipi/Curilla/Ayame/Nanaa Mihgo/Trion/Volker/Ajido-Marujido/Iron Eater/Prishe/Ulmia/Shikaree Z/Cherukiki/Gadalar/Zazarg/Nashmeira/Gessho/Ingrid/Maat/Arciela/Chacharoon] can be found in [San d'Oria/Bastok/Windurst/Jeuno/Tavnazia/Aht Urhgan/Adoulin/the Mod Gardens].
15549 : My well has run dry. There is nothing more I can proffer you.
15550 : Oh ho! You've got % on hand, do you?
15551 : Funny story, that. They are also involved in the Trust initiative.
15552 : I must bow my head in appreciation for all that you and your ilk have done for us. From the bottom of my heart, thank you.
15553 : I am more than pleased to report that your activities on our behalf have aided the institute in posting never-before-seen results.
15554 : Always cherish the bonds you have formed with that person, for such resilient ties take years--decades!--to form.
15555 : May your trust and friendship blossom into the envy of all!
15556 : Wh-who? This old mind does not work like it used to, for I know not one whit about that person.
15557 : Bah! What exactly am I supposed to do with this pile of nonsense?

15999 : Store Reinforcement Points for equipment? Yes. (Cost: # )) No.
16000 : Unity Concord is a system promulgated and managed by the Adventurers' Mutual Aid Network.
16001 : Participating adventurers are able to receive a variety of benefits and rewards just by engaging in their everyday activities.
16002 : Unity is a catchall term that refers to the group that participants belong to.
16003 : Unity leaders are individuals who have strong ties to adventurers' activities and are sterling representatives of their home nations.
16004 : Members of the same Unity can converse with each other over great distances through the use of specialized figurines known as %.
16005 : Chat settings may be changed by selecting Status from the main menu, and choosing Unity Info under the Unity submenu.
16006 : You may not always be able to join the chat if too many players are participating at once.
16007 : Those belonging to a Unity are able to undertake special Records of Eminence objectives related to Unity Concord activities.
16008 : The three pertinent categories include shared objectives, Unity leader-specific objectives, and Wanted battle objectives.
16009 : Shared objectives may be taken regardless of which Unity you have joined. These tasks can be undertaken at any time, and change every day at midnight (JST).
16010 : Unity leader-specific objectives are tied to the Unity's eponymous leader and change each week.
16011 : Wanted objectives center around vanquishing particularly heinous foes that terrorize Vana'diel.
16012 : These objectives are of a higher caliber, and thus require currency known as Unity accolades to undertake.
16013 : Shared and leader-specific objectives provide more accolades than run-of-the-mill objectives.
16014 : Vana'diel has always been plagued by nefarious foes pillaging the landscape, but relatives of some of the more heinous ones have been spotted lately.
16015 : The A.M.A.N. has deemed it necessary to eliminate these Wanted targets, and has notified Unity members that they are of the utmost priority.
16016 : A list of these foes can be viewed at any time by selecting the appropriate subcategory under the objectives list.
16017 : Unity Concord representatives are able to provide participants with transportation to the areas where these threats can be found.
16018 : Though tackling the profane will likely require participation of your allies, the objective can be undertaken so long as at least one person has set the appropriate objective.
16019 : When you set the objective and commence the battle, the requisite number of Unity accolades will be deducted from your total.
16020 : Successful challengers will be rewarded with special rewards in addition to the normal sparks of eminence.
16021 : No Unity accolades will be charged should you commence the battle without having the appropriate objective set, but the rewards you can reap from your efforts will be limited.
16022 : You can snatch unparalleled equipment and materials from the slain corpses of Wanted targets.
16023 : An A.M.A.N. specialist versed in arcane harmonization has kindly offered to use these materials to bring out the latent potential in such pieces.
16024 : One of the Unity guides will be pleased to accept certain combinations of equipment and materials to begin the process for you.
16025 : A number of accolades is required for this service, but the precision and accuracy of her methods are without equal, and there is no worry of your equipment being destroyed.
16026 : You can use specified materials to add new attributes to equipment that has been upgraded.
16027 : Utilizing additional materials after adding an attribute can accumulate Reinforcement Points for the equipment and increase its rank.
16028 : Increasing your equipment's rank can boost its attributes, while some equipment can also have additional attributes added later.
16029 : Speak to the Unity guides after gathering the necessary materials for your equipment in order to add attributes to it or increase its rank.
16030 : The first time you add an attribute to a piece of equipment will require the use of Unity accolades.
16031 : It also requires that you first complete a specific Records of Eminence objective.
16032 : The work you request will be carried out on-site by a specially trained Unity guide.
16033 : Completing Records of Eminence objectives as part of a Unity will reward you with Unity accolades in addition to sparks of eminence.
16034 : These accolades not only serve as a symbol of prestige, but can also be exchanged for a variety of services.
16035 : Some of these services include purchasing items, securing battle zones for hunting Wanted targets, fees for strengthening equipment, and more.
16036 : Please note that you may only exchange a maximum of # accolades per week (Earth time).
16037 : You may switch Unities once during the Unity ranking tabulation period.
16038 : This is not a decision to be taken lightly, for switching Unities will cause you to forfeit any benefits you were receiving from your previous one.
16039 : This process requires a fair deal of paperwork, and the A.M.A.N. will charge you an accolade fee based on your rank.
16040 : However, your valorous deeds remain wherever you choose to go, and you will not lose any other accolades.
16041 : Rankings are decided through the combined efforts of each of the Unity's members.
16042 : The A.M.A.N. tabulates all the good deeds done during a period of time and confers benefits on a Unity for the following ranking period.
16043 : Some of these benefits include changes to Unity accolades gained and the effects of equipment earned from Wanted battles.
16044 : Yes, you read that correctly--the attributes of certain equipment will increase in line with your Unity's ranking.
16045 : On the other hand, members of a Unity that finds itself on the lower rungs will enjoy an increase in accolades and capacity points earned to help bring them up to par.
16046 : Additionally, an individual's evaluation is the sum of the accolades they have earned divided by #. A Unity's ranking is the average of all eligible members' individual evaluations.
16047 : The A.M.A.N. does not look kindly on those who only seek to siphon rewards from others' hard work, and thus only confers these boons on those who have collected at least a certain number of accolades.
16048 : Unity leaders may also join you as alter egos for a limited period of time.
16049 : Those with evaluations of # or greater will be able to call forth an alter ego of their leader to assist them in battle.
16050 : Those eligible will be able to use the alter ego from the moment they acquire the appropriate ranking level until the tabulation after the next.
16051 : A leader's alter ego grows in power the higher their Unity is ranked.
16052 : Changing Unities will remove the player's ability to call forth their leader's alter ego at the moment they leave their current Unity, regardless of personal evaluation or remaining time.
16053 : A player will have to work hard in their new Unity and acquire a sufficient evaluation to regain the ability to call forth their new Unity's leader.
16054 : It goes without saying that players must first have acquired a Trust permit in order to avail themselves of this opportunity.

16601 : [Hi there!/Hello, friend!] I see you got letter I give to moogle.
16602 : Happy 20th Vana'versary!
16603 : I hope you ready to play Mandragora Mania Madness!
16604 : Since this new game, would you like to check rules in manual?
16605 : Read the manual? Sure. No thanks.
16606 : Mandragora Mania Madness is a game in which players battle by placing different colored game pieces on a 4x4 playing area.
16607 : You use the white pieces (mandragoras), while your opponent uses the black pieces (corrigans).
16608 : The player to go first is determined randomly when the game begins. You will be able to adjust these settings yourself from the second game onward.
16609 : The first player to place four pieces so they align in a row will be declared the winner.
16610 : However, you will automatically be disqualified if you ever place three of your pieces in a row, so be mindful of your moves at all times.
16611 : Note that if you place your game pieces so that you have both three and four pieces in a row, the row with four pieces will take precedence and you will win the game.
16612 : If you place a game piece on either side of your opponent's piece, you will convert it into one of your pieces.
16613 : You can play anywhere from three to five games, and the first player to win three games is the winner.
16614 : Now, for an explanation on points.
16615 : You receive points after the completion of each game. The points are tallied using units known as mandy.
16616 : If you win the game, you will receive a number of points equal to the number of game pieces you have on the board. In the example shown, you will earn 8 mandy.
16617 : Even if you lose the game, you will receive a number of points equal to half the number of your game pieces on the board (rounded off to avoid fractions).
16618 : The first player to win three games gets to keep all of the points they have earned, although you won't get any points if you quit partway.
16619 : Occasionally, you might get to play a bonus game, where your pieces are pink (adenium) or feature a watermelon pattern (citrullus).
16620 : They are worth #x and #x the points, respectively, giving you the chance to quickly score a large number of points.
16621 : The key to victory is to not just try and place four pieces in a row, but to position your pieces in a way that forces your opponent to place three pieces in a row.
16622 : See? Is very easy! Ready to give try?
16623 : You get mandy if you win or lose, but not if you quit partway!
16624 : Can trade mandy for many goodies.
16625 : Then I just give one piece of advice.
16626 : You get mandy if you win or lose, but not if you quit partway!
16627 : You can look at manual later if you need reminder on how to play.
16628 : Let's get to playing!

16666 : This is an explanation of the Assist Channel feature, which allows new and returning players to seek help from veteran adventurers.
16667 : You must take on the % Records of Eminence objective before receiving the explanation.
16668 : You must complete % before taking on the % Records of Eminence objective.
16669 : What do you want to learn about? What is the Assist Channel? How can I post a message? What are the requirements? Where can I access it? Tell me about mentor messages. Where can I find mentors? What are Thumbs Up and Warnings? What happens if I am muted? When do my posting rights expire? Nothing for now.
16670 : The Assist Channel is a special chat channel that allows adventurers to ask questions and receive advice from veteran players known as mentors.
16671 : Press the space bar to bring up the text window at the bottom of the screen and type /assistj (your message) or /assiste (your message) to post your message.
16672 : You can also use /aj for /assistj, and /ae for /assiste.
16673 : Additionally, pressing CTRL+Q will display /assistj or /assiste in the text window for you.
16674 : You can change the CTRL+Q shortcut command...
16675 : ...by going to Main Menu > Config > Misc. 2 > Key Assignment > Commands > Chat: /AssistE or /AssistJ.
16676 : It is recommended that you use /assistj (/aj) when posting in Japanese, and /assiste (/ae) when posting in English.
16677 : You must meet one of the following conditions in order to post to the Assist Channel.
16678 : 1. You are a new player You may post messages from the moment you first set foot in Vana'diel.
16679 : 2. You are a returnee As a returning player, you may post messages upon logging in with a character that has not logged in for at least 48 days.
16680 : 3. You are a mentor You may post messages as long as you remain a mentor to other players.
16681 : New players and returnees may post messages until they have been logged in for a total of 48 hours since first receiving their posting rights.
16682 : If you wish to check how long you can continue to post for, speak to an  and choose "When do my posting rights expire?" to see how much time you have left.
16683 : The Assist Channel can only be used in the following areas.
16684 : Available areas: %, %, %, %, %%
16685 : ...%%%%%%%%
16686 : ...%, %, %, %, %, %, %, %...
16687 : ...%, %, %, and your Mog House (Rent-a-Room).
16688 : You cannot post or read messages outside of the areas listed above.
16689 : Even in areas where messages are allowed, you cannot post consecutive messages. Please wait a while after posting a message.
16690 : Mentor messages are accompanied by a flag () marker. This marker indicates the mentor's reliability (Mentor Class) and experience as an adventurer (Mastery Rank).
16691 : As a mentor's Mentor Class increases, the color and shape of the marker will change:  >  >
16692 : A  marker is a sign that the mentor has earned the highest levels of trust from other adventurers.
16693 : The number affixed to the marker is the mentor's Mastery Rank, and indicates how experienced the mentor is as an adventurer.
16694 : The higher the number, the more experienced the mentor is.
16695 : You can check your own Mastery Rank even if you do not serve as a mentor, so feel free to take a look every now and then if you are curious.
16696 : You can check your Mastery Rank by going to Main Menu > Status > Profile.
16697 : If you wish to speak directly to a mentor, you can search for mentors by going to Main Menu > Help Desk > Mentor Search.
16698 : The Thumbs Up feature enables you to let mentors know when their comments proved to be especially helpful.
16699 : Mentors who earn lots of Thumbs Up replies from other adventurers will see their Mentor Class increase.
16700 : Remember to give a Thumbs Up to any mentor you feel helped you out or taught you something useful.
16701 : A Warning is a feature that can only be used by mentors.
16702 : Please use this feature when a post's contents are insufficient or otherwise may be construed as harassment.
16703 : To send a Thumbs Up or Warning to another player, open the Chat Log Window and move the cursor over the relevant message and press the confirm button (Enter key) to bring up the evaluation menu.
16704 : Evaluations can be made for 10 minutes following the designated player's latest post to the Assist Channel.
16705 : You may send up to one Thumbs Up and one Warning per day (Earth time).
16706 : The Mute feature places restrictions on your ability to post, meaning that other players will be unable to see the messages you post to the Assist Channel.
16707 : Please refrain from posting unsuitable content so that the veteran adventurers are not forced to mute you.
16708 : Mute status can be removed by players that have the necessary Mute List access rights, or it will be removed automatically 24 hours (Earth time) after the mute status was enabled.
16709 : You are free to post messages to the Assist Channel until you decide to stop serving as a mentor.
16710 : You may post messages to the Assist Channel until #:# on #/#/#. (Time remaining: Approx. # [sec./min./hr.])
16711 : If you log out while you still have time available, your remaining time will be carried over to the next time you log in.
16712 : You are about to lose the ability to post messages to the Assist Channel.
16713 : You are unable to post messages to the Assist Channel.
16714 : Take on the % Records of Eminence objective from the Tutorial section of the Records of Eminence Menu and speak to the A.M.A.N. liaison.
16715 : Good day, adventurer! I am able to repair any broken item data related to %.
16716 : If you are unable to deliver %, it's possible that the item data has been corrupted.
16717 : Please trade your % to me so that I may fix it.
16718 : I have confirmed that the item data for your % has been corrupted. We apologize for the inconvenience.
16719 : I have restored it to its intended functionality. Here you are!
16720 : It appears that your item is working as intended.
16721 : An error has occurred. Please try again later.
16722 : Here you can play the game Mandragora Mania.

16739 : Read the manual? Sure. No thanks.
16740 : Mandragora Mania is a game in which you battle for jingly by moving your mandragora pieces to the goal.
16741 : Your goal is the [red/blue/green] one on the right, while your opponent's is the [blue/green/red] one on the left.
16742 : At the start of the game, three mandragoras each will be placed on the eight game areas, excluding the goal.
16743 : There are five starting placements (A through E), and you are able to select which one you would like to employ. The default setting is "Random."
16744 : This explanation uses pattern A, but the basic rules are the same regardless of the starting pattern.
16745 : The three [red/blue/green] areas in front of you are yours,the three [blue/green/red] areas at the back are your opponent's,and the remaining two are neutral.
16746 : You must choose one area--either yours or a neutral one--to proceed.
16747 : The areas are numbered from one to five starting from the left, and any mandragoras in the area you select will move.
16748 : Conversely, your opponent must select either a neutral area or an area that belongs to them.
16749 : From the right, those areas are numbered 6, 4, 7, 2, and 8.
16750 : For example, if you select Area 1,one mandragora will move to Area 2and one will move to Area 3,and one will move to Area 4.
16751 : Note that the mandragoras will move from the back first--last in, first out.
16752 : You will receive points known as jingly each time one of your mandragoras reaches the goal.
16753 : You will enter your opponent's territory whenever you go past the goal.
16754 : If one of your mandragoras happens to reach the opponent's goal, the goal will be pushed back and your mandragora will return to your own area. You don't have to worry about your mandragora earning any jingly for your opponent.
16755 : The order in which players choose areas will be determined based on your turn settings. The default setting is random.
16756 : This explanation has skipped past your opponent's turn for demonstration purposes, but in the actual game you and your opponent will take turns choosing areas.
16757 : However, if the last mandragora to move reaches the goal, you will get to take an additional turn.
16758 : Mandragoras are a very diverse species, and the amount of jingly you earn is determined by the species of mandragora that crosses into the goal.
16759 : Adenium and citrullus: 3 jingly (first player)/4 jingly (second player).
16760 : Korrigan and pachypodium: 2 jingly (first player)/3 jingly (second player).
16761 : Standard mandragoras: 1 jingly (both players).
16762 : The game is over when either you or your opponent no longer has any mandragoras that can move.
16763 : The player who has the most jingly at that point will be declared the winner.
16764 : The key to victory lies in taking advantage of the various mandragora subspecies bonuses while claiming multiple turns in a row.
16765 : Pattern [A/B/C/D/E] - Your Turn ([First Player/Second Player])
16766 : ou have selected Area #.
16767 : ou receive # jingly for a total of #.
16768 : Pattern [A/B/C/D/E] - Your Turn ([Second Player/First Player])
16769 : Your opponent has selected Area #.
16770 : Your opponent receives # jingly for a total of #.
16771 : ame Complete!
16772 : [Victory!/Defeat!/Draw!] (# - #)

16774 : That area has no mandragora to move.

16776 : Really give up? Yes. No.
16777 : ou receive # jingly for a total of #.
16778 : You have reached the jingly cap of #. Any additional jingly will be lost.
